title: MathLedger: A Verifiable Learning Substrate with Ledger-Attested Feedback
raw_snippet: arXiv:2601.00816v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Contemporary AI systems achieve extraordinary performance yet remain opaque and non-verifiable, creating a crisis of trust for safety-critical deployment. title: CogCanvas: Verbatim-Grounded Artifact Extraction for Long LLM Conversations
raw_snippet: arXiv:2601.00821v2 Announce Type: new Abstract: Conversation summarization loses nuanced details: when asked about coding preferences after 40 turns, summarization recalls "use type hints" but drops the critical constraint "everywhere" (19.0% exact match vs. 93.0% for our approach). title: Energy-Aware Routing to Large Reasoning Models
raw_snippet: arXiv:2601.00823v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large reasoning models (LRMs) have heterogeneous inference energy costs based on which model is used and how much it reasons. title: Decomposing LLM Self-Correction: The Accuracy-Correction Paradox and Error Depth Hypothesis
raw_snippet: arXiv:2601.00828v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are widely believed to possess self-correction capabilities, yet recent studies suggest that intrinsic self-correction--where models correct their own outputs without external feedback--remains largely ineffective. title: Can We Trust AI Explanations? Evidence of Systematic Underreporting in Chain-of-Thought Reasoning
raw_snippet: arXiv:2601.00830v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: When AI systems explain their reasoning step-by-step, practitioners often assume these explanations reveal what actually influenced the AI's answer. title: Enhancing Temporal Awareness in LLMs for Temporal Point Processes
raw_snippet: arXiv:2601.00845v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Temporal point processes (TPPs) are crucial for analyzing events over time and are widely used in fields such as finance, healthcare, and social systems. title: Temporal Attack Pattern Detection in Multi-Agent AI Workflows: An Open Framework for Training Trace-Based Security Models
raw_snippet: arXiv:2601.00848v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We present an openly documented methodology for fine-tuning language models to detect temporal attack patterns in multi-agent AI workflows using OpenTelemetry trace analysis.
